newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israelis wound dozens of Palestinians in clashes.
newsitem.headline: Israelis wound dozens of Palestinians in clashes.

text.p: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least 38 Palestinians in the third day of clashes with stone-throwing Arabs in the divided West Bank town of Hebron on Monday, witnesses and hospital officials said.

In Gaza, Jewish settlers shot and wounded one Palestinian youth and fired at least three bullets at journalists during a clash over land which Arabs said had recently been fenced off and annexed to the Gush Qatif settlement bloc.
The violence underscored rising Israel-PLO tensions over a three month deadlock in peace efforts and what Palestinians view as an Israeli drive to expand Jewish settlements in Gaza and the West Bank.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused the Palestinian Authority on Monday of ordering the violence in Gaza and of doing nothing to stop unrest in Hebron.

"There was a clear set of instructions a few days ago in Gaza for the violence that took place there," Netanyahu told reporters after he addressed a parliamentary committee in Jerusalem, referring to unrest last Thursday.
"I can't tell you about Hebron in the last 24 hours because I haven't seen the reports. But I can tell you that the Palestinian police have refrained from acting against the violence," he said.
The fiercest unrest erupted in Hebron along an invisible line that divides the city into Israeli and Palestinian-controlled areas.
Witnesses said Israeli soldiers fired rubber-coated bullets at about 100 youths who were hurling stones and petrol bombs.

They said at least 38 Palestinians, including an 11-year-old boy, were wounded in the clashes. Officials at the city's Alia hospital said surgeons were trying to remove a rubber-coated bullet from the boy's mouth.
Some of the wounded were treated by doctors who set up a first-aid area in the courtyard of a Hebron petrol station, a few hundred metres away from the fighting.
The Israeli army said in a statement one border policeman was hit by a stone and slightly wounded. It said troops dispersed the demonstrators.
Palestinians said Israeli troops had refrained from using tear gas to quell complaints from the city's 400 Jewish settlers that the fumes were affecting them. The army declined comment.

Israeli soldiers shot and wounded about 45 Arabs on Saturday and Sunday during clashes that erupted over a recent U.S. House of Representatives vote calling on President Bill Clinton to recognise Arab East Jerusalem as part of Israel's capital.
Faisal al-Husseini, the PLO's top official in Jerusalem, and Palestinian legislators demonstrated earlier on Monday near the U.S. Consulate in East Jerusalem to protest against the vote.
Israel handed 80 percent of Hebron to Palestinian rule in January under an interim peace deal but kept troops in parts of the town to protect the settler enclaves.
In the Gaza Strip, Jewish settlers shot and wounded a Palestinian youth in the knee when angry Arabs tried to remove a fence erected by Gush Katif settlers, witnesses said.
They said settlers also fired three bullets at Palestinian journalists on the scene. None was wounded.
"I shouted to the settler in Hebrew that we were reporters, but he swore at us and continued to fire his pistol. One bullet barely missed us," a Reuters reporter said.
A settler spokesman confirmed a clash had taken place but said he knew nothing about shooting at journalists.
"They broke into our farming village...and started destroying property. Our residents kicked them out," Gush Katif settler spokesman Shlomo Kostiner told Reuters.
Witnesses said Israeli soldiers who arrived on the scene kicked and punched reporters and fired tear gas at the demonstrators who had camped near the site.
